name: Irretractable
description:
While trying to prove that two functions `f : A → B` and `g : B → A` form an isomorphism between `A` and `B`, I sometimes find it much easier to prove the [section](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_(category_theory)) (`∀ a → g (f a) ≡ a`) than to prove the retraction (`∀ b → f (g b) ≡ b`). But why should I need to prove the retraction? By proving the section I have already shown that the functions are inverses of each other... Why does the proof of isomorphism require both?

But we are using a proof language! Why speculate when we can prove it to ourselves!

### Task

Prove that a section between two functions is not enough to show that the two functions form an isomorphism.

### Preloaded

```agda
record IsIsomorphism {A B : Set} (f : A → B) (g : B → A) : Set where
  constructor IsIso
  field
    section : ∀ (a : A) → g (f a) ≡ a
    retract : ∀ (b : B) → f (g b) ≡ b
```
